name: Jamestown
description: Jamestown: Legend Of The Lost Colony is a neo-classical top-down shooter for up to 4 players, set on 17th-century British Colonial Mars. It features all the intensity, depth, and lovingly handcrafted pixels of a classic arcade shooter, with a modern twist: deeply-integrated cooperative gameplay.
minimum_requirements: OS: Microsoft® Windows® XP with SP2 / Vista / 7  Processor: Intel® Pentium™ 4 2.4 GHz or better Memory: 512 MB RAM Hard Disk Space: 250 MB  Video Card: Any OpenGL 2.0 graphics card with 256MB+ video RAM and full GLSL support DirectX®: DirectX® 9.0c Additional: One keyboard, controller, or mouse required per player. Supports multiple mice and/or keyboards. 3-buttons required for mouse play.

reviews.review_text: Jamestown is an extremely solid shmup, with one really fantastic advantage over other shmups.  As a single player game, it doesn't match the classics it takes inspiration from. The bullet patterns and level designs are solid but also a bit bland and lacking in strategic variety. It's good, but not great.  Where it really shines is multiplayer, as unlike the tacked on co op of your average Cave game, Jamestown's mechanics and gameplay were finely balanced around co op from the start. It's probably the best co op shmup ever made, and that's definitely something to brag about.  It also has one of the best and most creative settings and aesthetics for a shmup outside of a Cave game. The theme, music, pixel art, and setting are excellent.  If you don't have anyone to play with (local multiplayer only), than Jamestown is a decent shmup that should probably be somewhere in the middle of your wishlist compared to some of the other excellent PC shmups out there. However, if you have some friends to play with, it's an absolute must buy.

It is 90s' vertical arcade shooter with enhanced features and presentation!  Good: - Beautiful 2D pixel drawings, very rare to see in nowadays, about the top notch graphic level of previous NeoGeo games - Marvelous Soundtrack, match the story background neatly - Great control response and very accurate hit box detection - Pretty enemy designs - Various modes and challenge adds replayablility - Wide screen vertical shooters is eyes friendly - Local Coop up to 4 players, I don't complaint the lack of Online mode as I can see it won't goes well with current Internet environment for such tense response game  Bad: - Scenario stages is quite short, I don't mind to buy DLC to extend the joy  Suggestion: - Vault Bulletshield is same for all Ships. If every Ships can varie with such as Slow-mo, Bullet reflection, Bullet Breakshot, Bullet Blackhole or etc.  Score: 85/100

This game slowly turns you into a real man. You start like 'yeah, normal difficulty' and then you realize that to finish the game you need to gradually increase the difficulty of every stage, making you play every freaking level on legendary difficulty and teaching you that the bullet hell is a real place where you will be sent there at the first sign of defiance.  TL;DR great bullethell topdown shooter arcade thingy, a great challenge.

Disclosure: I marked “received this product for free” because I received it as a gift.  Jamestown: Legend Of The Lost Colony is a game that I wanted to play at one time. Before I make a purchase I typically check out reviews (both good and bad) and the Steam Discussions to see if there is anything that might make me think twice about buying. If the game crashes on start or has some sort of other technical issue there is a good chance someone will be posting about it. In the case of Jamestown, one doesn't have to look far to find some dirt.  When I looked through the discussions I learned that Final Form Games appear to have completely abandoned the PC version of the game (it looks like they stopped support to focus on PlayStation 4's Jamestown+). The developers haven't posted since June 24, 2015. There is at least one somewhat major bug that they're aware of and haven't fixed as of today August 28, 2016. For many users, every enemy projectile in the game is currently a dull grey color. The color of bullets in shooting games is kind of a big deal and there is a good reason why they often are colored brightly. How are you supposed to dodge them if you can't see them clearly? I've played quite a few shoot 'em ups and this was enough to convince me not to buy the game.   A fix exists, but it doesn't work for all users. It involves reverting to a previous version through the properties menu of the game in Steam. It ended up partially working for me. It fixed the colors but the game became unplayable unless played windowed. I strongly prefer fullscreen so decided to keep the grey bullets. Aside from not being aesthetically pleasing, there were only a few parts where I found them to be particularly detrimental. I also experienced odd controller bugs if I was holding a direction immediately while spawning. I'm not sure if it was my gamepad or not, but it wasn't difficult to avoid once I realized what was causing it.  Jamestown isn't really a standard arcade style shooting game. Rather than being one continuous run, the game is split up into five stages. In order to unlock all five stages the player is required to beat the earlier stages on progressively higher difficulty levels. The later stages do not feature lower difficulty options at all. This serves as a nice and slow introduction for individuals inexperienced with the genre. In addition to the regular stages there are challenge levels that feature special objectives such as flying through rings, getting a certain score within a time limit, or surviving a brief onslaught. The regular stages are enjoyable but I had even more fun with the challenges. The only campaign stage I didn't like was the final one which unexpectedly introduces environmental hazards which aren't in the earlier levels and felt out of place.  After completing a stage you are rewarded with ducats that can be used in the store. Among other things the store sells alternate ships, additional challenges, and the gauntlet mode. Each ship has a primary attack, a special secondary attack, and the ability to vaunt. Activating vaunt mode provides temporary invincibility, a damage bonus, and a score multiplier. Picking up coins prolongs the amount of time your retain the bonuses. The Gauntlet serves as the game's version of an arcade mode where you play through all the stages consecutively with limited continues. It is also worth mentioning that the game allows up to four players. I never tested multiplayer out myself so I can't say how well it works.  Although it's a little unorthodox when compared to classic Japanese arcade shooters, Jamestown is one of the strongest entries into the shoot 'em up genre from a western developer that I've ever played. It's truly sad that Final Form Games has let it fall into its current state. The game is gorgeous, the soundtrack is great, and the overall presentation is outstanding. Due to the solid package and enjoyable gameplay I'd recommend this game, but with a warning about the likelihood of encountering bugs. There is a lot of fun to be had here and it's playable even with the grey bullets, but I think it's important that potential buyers know that there are bugs that may never be fixed.    Like the review? Follow my curator page to see my thoughts on other games.

Really enjoyable bullethell shooter, Jamestown is a good choice for some couch co-op fun. The controls work about equally well with mouse, keyboard or a gamepad and there are several difficulty levels, although like most bullethell games it leans towards being hard. The graphics are well made with detailed backgrounds, the soundtrack is excellent and there are several mini challenges as well as a funny dialogue option which give variety to the core game. Its weaknesses would be its small level variety as well as the lack of online co-op. I do recommend nevertheless, especially for local co-op purposes, where you will get the most out of it.

Jamestown is a shoot'em up (shmup) that pleased me greatly. The game's story is set in a fictitious alternative past in the XVII century, where the planet Mars is a British colony that is at war with Spanish forces allied with the native Martians. Some real historical characters of the period even are mentioned in the game as the famous John Smith. Jamestown has a very good vertical gameplay, being that the game has four types of ships, each ship has a normal shot and another special. There is also the 'Vaunt Mode' that can be activated when the gold bar is full. The 'Vaunt Mode' when activated generates a temporary shield around the ship and also allows double the damage and also the points earned while active. The 2D graphics of this game are well done and the controls work well, but the highest point of the game is the soundtrack ... it's superb! Especially the tracks of Chapters 1, 3 and 5 that are simply wonderful! Jamestown: The Legend of Lost Colony captivated me and was quite enjoyable for me to finish it. Too see me playing Jamestown's, please check the videos below:          Jamestown [HD] - Playthrough [Part 1/5] Chapter I

After decades, someone has found the courage to tell the truth about this forgotten page of british colonial history. James I Stuart landed on Mars and fought natives and Spanish, but the Cromwellians hid all his conquers for centuries!  Great shmup, it's worth your money.

This is a great bullet hell style overhead shooter with viberant hand drawn graphics and a stunning sountrack and oddly enough a good orginal story, which is rare for a shoot 'em up. Now it is a bit on the short side with only 6 stages total(hopefully they will add more in future DLC) but given that you have to finish previous stages on certain difficulty levels in order to play the last two it does extend the game a bit, plus there's tons of challange maps to helpkeep you busy and did I mention this is a blast in multiplayer? No.. well it is.

Let me start off by saying that i've not played any 'bullet hell' games before.   Jamestown was my introduction to the genre, and what a great introduction it was.   Although i've yet to plow through it with a buddy on Judgement difficulty, it's great fun to play with and without a partner.   The aim is to survive every level by dodging all of the projectiles that the enemy fires towards you and to simply survive 'til the end, where there'll be a boss awaiting for you to defeat.   There's a good variety of ships to use that all have different tactics and methods of progressing the stages and they're all entertaining to use.   The DLC is well worth it, too. So don't hesitate to pick it up - it'll give you some brand new ships to add to your arsenal. A great game, well worth your time.  All in all, i'm giving it an 8/10.

One of the best top down shooters I've played in a while. You're liable to have fun even if you're like me and aren't a big fan of the genre. If you've got a buddy, a keyboard and a mouse you already have some fun multiplayer going on, easy to learn, hard to master.  Seriously, worth the $10.
Ultimately quite short, but the extra difficulty and bonus levels add a lot of replayaility. Classic gameplay that does the classic 'shoot'em up' genre exceptionally well.

Astoundingly good as a pick-up-and-go party game and great for when you might not have all the controllers you were looking for. Very targeted towards non-hardcore players, which makes the game a lot more fun.
I like videogames.  This one in particular.

A very fun and very good shmup. The graphics are fantastic, excellent vibrant pixel art crawling with details and wonderful animations. It looks fantastic in motion. The controls are very smooth, the vault and special buttons are very well implemented and the different types of ships each make for a slightly different twist on the game. I like the Gunner myself and the ability to steer bullets ala options in Gradius 5. The game is highly replayable thanks to multiple difficulty levels and the levels themselves are rather short. Each level can be played through in under 5 minutes. True there are only 5 levels in the core game, but I keep revisiting them time and time again. The addition of multiplayer and score rankings only adds to the fun. Besides the 5 main levels there are challenge levels and lots of unlockables to unlock. Gameplay wise this is one of the finest shooters I've played - and I'm an avid shmup fan. For the money and the value, you really can't go wrong here.
Not much to say about top-down shooters, you either like them or you don't. This one is done right. The backgroung art and story are interesting and worth playing if you like these games.

Fun and good looking vertical shooter. Great for those times where you're not sure what to play and have some time to kill. Game is very easy to get into, but also has some upgrades available to make it more interesting. It has plenty of difficulty levels, so everyone will find one that fits them.
Scroller 'like retro', awessome music, and only HARDCORE!
touhou with cowboys
This is 'hands down' one of the best games I have ever played.
Nerve wrecking, but a lot of fun :D

One of the best western produced vertical shooters I've ever played. Right up there with stuff like Tyrian. It has fun gameplay, different playable ships, and a handful of unlockables. While higher difficulties can feel like a bullet hell shooter sometimes, there's usually always a difficulty setting that feels satisfying for players of any skill level.   While it never reaches the insanity that Ikaruga or Touhou provides, Jamestown is still a moderately challenging shmup experience. It's well polished and a decent game all around. Recommended to anyone who enjoys shooters really.
The best game of its genre! If you liked the 1941 & 1942 flying arcade games, this is like 100 times better
Brings me back to the good old days. Easy to play and fun!
I absolutely love this game!
I absolutely love this game!

This is a really great scrolling shooter. It's technical, but not overly complicated. The gameplay is fast, just how I like it, and is great to play with friends (4 players in all). When you've finished all of the story mode on all the difficulties, you then can try out the same in gauntlet mode, and even after that you still have 20 or so challenges to do. It seems to keep on going like Super Smash Bros, and Mario Kart did. You refine your technic little by little and have great fun doing so.

This is the best game I ever got by accident. It was part of a humble bundle that I bought just for the game Closure, and had no intention of playing Jamestown. Ironically, I ended up playing Closure for all of 20 minutes, and I've invested nearly 10 hours into this one. I rarely even play shooters, and yet this game is thoroughly addicting and enjoyable. What I like most is the simplicity. It takes 5 minutes to learn everything there is to know about how to play, and you can jump right in on the lowest difficulty and have some fun without getting crushed right away. The difficulty scales very well, and each stage requires you to beat all the previous stages on a higher difficulty level than the one before to unlock the next stage. It's a natural progression, and is suitable even for someone like myself who isn't a veteran to these types of games.  That being said, there are only five stages in the game which are each very short, but they are well designed and have high replay value. On top of that there are five challenge packs that you can purchase using in game currency, which range from challenging to rage inducing. But what really makes this game most enjoyable are the beautiful 16-bit sprites and the art direction. A high level of detail was put into each stage, and some of the backgrounds are gorgeous. It's only too bad you don't have much time to look at them as you're constantly dodging bullets. It's got that classic old school look but at the same time has an aesthetic all its own. Plus the explosions look great, and I love how you collect gold from each enemy you destroy. Each time you blow up a ship and those chunks of gold pieces come falling down the screen, it's a real treat and feels so rewarding. Oh, and the soundtrack is awesome too. All in all, if you're a fan of schmup games, this is a must buy. I paid practically nothing for it, but can say it's easily worth 10 bucks. And if you can get it on sale ($4.99 when I wrote this) then it's a no brainer.
Nice twist of an old-fashion arcade shooter. Not too complex, not too simple.
Short, but funny and pretty. Lke it anyway. It`s worth your time=)
A fun old-school top-down shooter. Quite a challenge, too :)
Old-school bullet hell fun.
Steampunk Touhou with boys and ships.

Quite a fun little game and quick to pick up... but as soon as you step up the difficulty there are bullets everywhere! Certainly a game for twitch players with cat-like reflexes. Definitely worth the money.
pretty damn amazing, for an indie game

This is one of the hardest bullet hells you will ever play. (Unless you play touhou). This game has 4 player co-op, extra ships, dlc, extreme hard levels, and extreme fun. With 4 buddies, and 4 360 controllers, the fun (and sometimes rage) is limiteless! Especially at this low pricepoint this game is a steal. ~PR0XIDIAN

I'm a fan of bullet hell game but this is not your typical levels and guns. The uniqueness of each level - the theme, level design, music is so well done I can't put this game down. Jamestown is hands down the most epic and most beautiful bullet hell game I've ever played... Love it!

With over 30 hours logged, this is hands-down the best value-for-money game I own to date. It's a great little retro game with fantastic graphics and music and very addicting gameplay. It's also great multiplayer and there are several different ships to master (more with the expansion), as well as 5 different difficulty levels and a number of bonus challenges. I only wish there were more levels!

Jamestown is an old school bullet hell arcade shooter, but with 4 player co-op. In that regard already it's quite unique and interesting. The only way to make bullet hell games more visually chaotic is the addition of more players. But what makes Jamestown more interesting is it's setting, story, and presentation. It's basicly a sci-fi steam-punk neo-classical retelling of the early days of the English American colonies. You face the forces of the Martian/Spanish alliance in hopes of being pardoned for a crime against the English crown. The orchestral soundtrack and story scenes somehow make this seem more epic than you expect, even if it is a bit silly. And the entire package feels polished and well made. There are unlockables and bonus missions to keep dragging you back, even if it is a short game; and there're always high scores to be challenged. One of my favourite bullet-hell games ever.
I finally had time to play Jamestown and man, it's awesome! I allways likes bullet hell shooters and this is definitly a great addition to the genre!
Jamestown extemely well done as a game. Despite being incredibly difficult, my friends and I always have a blast playing
The most Historically accurate game you will ever play.
It's not Touhou (not even close), but it's beautiful, it has great music, and it's fun. Bring friends. Just beware that the game is very short.

Jamestown is a top-down arcade-style space shooter like Raiden or Galaga with very beautiful 16-bit-style pixel art and very fun, modern gameplay.  I normally really enjoy these sorts of games, and not suprsingly, I enjoyed this one too. Lots of enemies, lots of bullets, and the controls are good enough that you can deal with both. There are five difficulty settings and interesting bonus levels that increase replay value. But, what really made the game fun was the multiplayer. You can play locally with up to four players, using mouse, keyboard, or gamepads. I hadn't played a good local multiplayer game in a while, and this was a blast with three. There are four different ship types, so people can take on multiple roles in a group. Best to stick with the easiest type if you're going solo, though.  I just got it on sale, and it's already been worth the money for me. If you like this sort of game, then I think you'll enjoy this one too.

Excellent vertically scrolliing shooter in the vein of all those 80s arcade classics - 1942/1943, Salamander, and the like. Pixel perfect maneuvering, odd backgrounds, and bullets and lazers zooming by, all of which invariably ends with you either dying (because you weren't good enough), or you going 'W...T...F. How did I escape that?'  Definitely recommended if you're into shooters that aren't just twin-stick 'point-and-shoot' things.

Get this game now! There really isn't anything I can say that will do this game justice. It's an absolute blast to play and even more so with friends. Sure there's no online play but they did a great job at allowing multiple people play from the same PC. This is easily one of my favorite indie games. I hope to see more from this dev
1. 6+ levels.  2. Unlockable levels. 3. Improve your hand-eye-coordination. I recommend trying the hardest difficulty setting.
Great gameplay, epic music. This game is perfect for players with controllers!
Do you like Tyrian? Do you like Raptor: Call of the Shadows? Do you like U.N. Squadron? Then why the ♥♥♥♥ aren't you playing this game?

Alternative history steampunk bullet hell game, inspired by Japanese arcade shmups. Interesting and challenging for genre veterans and accessible for complete beginners. Has nicely done pixel art graphics, challenges, unlockables and co-op mode. Give it a try!
First game of this kind that I played, but I love it. It's quite addictive trying to improve your skills and learning how to beat the pretty hard levels.
Quite addictive, though the challenges are far to hard for me...

Oh, how I have missed the days of classic arcade-ish shooter style. Jamestown does this in a nice storyline. Play per-chapter, or unlock the Gauntlet mode and play this just like those arcade days! The tutorial helps you out quite a bit. This is one of my favorites now. :)

Bullet-Hell At It's Finest  I'm a sucker for pixels, games that make me want to punch a wall (if well made, not due to blatantly shoddy construction... i'm describing the games... not the wall), and fiction loosely based on actual events. Jamestown quenches all of these thirsts along with an unexpectedly stunning soundtrack to create a wonderful shooter for both the novice and the masochistic.  This top-down arcade sci-fi shmup is all about style. Difficulties can be chosen before each stage, ranging from the easiest resembling 1942 to Insane which will challenge any fan of the Touhou series. (If you don't know touhou, find it on youtube and it will make your eyes bleed. In a good way.)  Multiple ships (with more available via DLC!), a wide array of difficulties, and an in-game unlockables via gold gained for blowing things up and creating long bonus string allow for many return plays, for both quick breaks or marathon sessions.  One downside - The 4-player Coop is SINGLE MACHINE ONLY. There is no online option. It's great for having a few people together, but in this day and age, not having online multiplayer can really limit popularity of a title. But... THAT'S IT! Everything else is a big thumbs up.  It's even got an unlockable 'parody' mode. Doesn't change much, but it really adds a lovely transparency to the developers' love of oldschool shooters.  This is a shining example of what the indie game scene can do. Do yourself a favor and pick this beast up.

I can honestly say that this is a game I would recommend for all you bullet hell slash retro shooters out there, and even something for ADD twitch action junkies as well, and also high concept historical sci-fi buffs.
A really rad shmup. It's a pretty good bullet hell thing, you might like it if you're hardcore into them too. Classy too.
The ONLY thing missing from this game - Online multiplayer
One of the greatest bullet hell games released within 20years.... only wish its multi was online.... worth adding to your arcade collection.

You might not know what the heck this game even is. Understandably so, but it deserves to be recognized. Jamestown is a bullet-hell shooter catering to old-school classics. 4 Player offline fully enabled from the get-go will be the beginning of many hysterical screams and laughter when confronting the games most wicked challenges. Place this game at the top of awesome multiplayer house party experiences. Stylized and precise controls; it's your fault if you die. :)

A beautifully rendered game that combines the best of genre classics like Ikaruga and Touhou while still containing its own distinct gameplay mechanics, Jamestown proves that top-down shooters still have a place in today's video game pantheon. Well worth the admission price for genre fans, but still easily recommendable for those just wanting a fun game that calls back the Neo Geo era.
Easily one of the prettiest shooters out there.
Really fun arcade shooter with awesome artistic style and a wonderful soundtrack.
Worth it!
Fun game but I suggest against using it for any homework papers about Jamestown, but it was worth the c+

If you're into bullet-hell shooters, this is the game for you!  The gameplay is tight and well made, with four different ships to choose from (three that have to be unlocked through playing the game) with very different play styles. The visual aesthetic is unique and works well for the game. The story itself is pretty out there, but for a bullet-hell game, the story isn't really why we're here, now is it?  All in all, the game is worth the price, especially if you can get some friends together.

Bullethell shoot'em up with gorgeous Metal Slug-esque graphics. The game is short but has a lot of replay value from challenges, difficulty levels and leaderboards, also featuring up to 4 players local coop and a top-notch soundtrack.
Really fun old style shoot em up game. The only problem is that theres no online mode

This game manages to pack in a little something for everybody. While it's taken cues from common modern-day Flash games - including things like a shop with unlockables from points earned in-game, plus challenge levels and the like - it provides for the more hardcore shmup community as well with an arcade-style Gauntlet mode and enough points to unlock it right from the start. It also has a more classic difficulty progression, with some of the late-game stages only available to the higher difficulty levels.  Gameplay-wise, Final Form did their research before working on this. They followed the conventions of modern shoot-'em-ups and made sure to give it a polished feel. While there are a couple small things that bother me here and there (Dark Sector is quickly becoming That One Level for me), it's generally enjoyable all around no matter what kind of action experience you're into.
Oldskool arcade awesomenes, what more can you want ;)
A fantastic, arcade-quality bullet-hell shooter with the added bonus that, unlike most games in the genre, playing this won't legally disqualify you from working with children.
It's a weird shooter. Gets hard fast. Still worth a try, I guess.

It's not Ikaruga so it's not that great, but then anything that isn't Ikaruga isn't that great.  If you're never played Ikaruga, this is a really awesome game. The developers also have no idea what DLC is because this game is packed with lots of bonus and post game content. This is like the Superbowl of bullet hell shooters.

This game is very fun. It's a great foray into the Local Multiplayer on a PC field, and they do it beautifully. Easy integration with multiple mice, controllers and keyboard, make for a great experience all around! Definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants to have fun or if you have no friends, it's still fun. Not joking. Pick this up. Then put it down. If you have to go to sleep, it's okay to stop playing this game, but play it again in the future when you wake up. If you do. Please don't take too much ambien.  Love, Dan DeNinno

Not for the faint of heart or slow of thumb, Jamestown: Legend of the Lost Colony is a fantastic retro top down shooter that gets just about everything right. Starting off in your standard Beam ship, you blast through stages while learning about the new Martian Jamestown.
The best co-op shoot-em-up ever, and (thank God) its INDIE!, Buy (even at full price).  My score: 8/10
Jamestown is a top-down shooter with some awesome art and pretty darn fun co-op. It even has a cool setting for a top down shooter, which is pretty rare.

An interesting title with an awesome pixel art style and a music fitting it. The theme is rididulous but it just makes the game more interesting. Pity the story is sort of average from what I've played. As far as the cutscenes art go, not really my style, but I'm guessing it was an attempt at creating something fitting the story.  It isn't as extreme as Ikaruga, which is a plus for me since I can't play on that level. However this game brings out a lot of interesting mechanics I've never seen from the few titles I've played from the genre. You get different ship models each with an interesting superpower which just further engages you without getting to ridiculous missile spam.  Now the bad. The levels are short and you quickly get through half the story in about 20 mins. But then it orders you to play all three previous levels again in high difficulty in order to go through. This was a huge disapointment considering I hate replaying games.   Overall I recommend it but be prepared to spend quite some time replaying it if you don't go straight Difficult Mode from the start.
A fantastic bullet hell game with great music. Great stuff.

This is a great little shooter. My only gripe is that 4 levels in it tells you that you must replay the game on hard mode, not normal, to access the other levels. That's a bit lame as it's a story/campaign so we are 4 levels in and now have to replay them again.  It's still a... blast. ;)  Buy it.

I'm not great at shmups, but, for maybe the first time in the genre, that wasn't a prequisite for enjoying Jamestown. Perhaps even more unlikely was that a good portion of my enjoyment was due to a shmup's story: Jamestown combines colonial American history with spaceships, Mars, and aliens, then revels in the goofiness of it all. The result, thankfully, isn't B-movie schlock, but rather a charming, cartoonish world where I can feel at home shooting a ton of things and (mostly) avoiding a never-ending stream of bullets. And to that end, Jamestown is also extremely solid. The campaign is a fairly short experience, but there is a real draw to mastering levels on multiple difficulties and -- if you're skillful enough (I wasn't) -- working your way through the myriad one-life, scenario-driven challenge levels.

Fantastic art, fantastic music. What makes this game really shines for me is the local multiplayer, it's fun as hell! Only drawback is that there are only 5 levels, but it's okay since each one is very well-designed. This game is not nearly as difficult as those japanese bullet hells, but the gauntlet mode on hardest difficulty should put even seasoned players to test.
Fun game, throwback ti the old school side scrollers on par with metal slug.
I'm just about 30mins into the game and so far, it's great. Tight controls on the xbox controller and interesting boss fights so far. It's got an old school feel to it.
Holy smokes it's an awesome shump that doesn't require me to play as a underage anime girl.

I've played a bunch of bullet hell games (Ikaruga, Radiant Silvergun and Sine Mora to name a few) and while I'm not a real pro, I enjoy and appreciate this genre of games. Jamestown is one of those kinds of games that can get relentlessly difficult, yet give you warm ups to give you the practise needed for the higher difficulties as well as the challenges.  On Normal, the story missions aren't really difficult, but you can only play through the first three missions as each one after the third requires you to beat all unlocked missions on a higher difficulty, and it's through this that you develop the skills needed to complete this game. There are only six missions, but the requirements give each level a fair degree of difficulty to finish the main game.  There are also challenges and a Gauntlet Mode (which sends you through the story mode up to the levels given with the difficult you're on in one straight run. No lives or Credits restored. 2 Continues and 2 lives per continue will be all you get!) which will give you more to do after you finish the game. Not gonna lie, I haven't made much progress with those challenges yet, but completing each one is very rewarding considering how insane some of them are.  The ships themselves differ and cater to various play styles, including the DLC ships. I find myself using the Beam (the default ship) often, but I find the Ghost is a lot of fun, and a neat shout out to Guwange (another bullet hell style game where you control your main character and a spirit, basically how this ship operates).  The music, the style, the gameplay, it's all well done and none of it seems out of place or jarring. The story is a neat throwback to the days of crazy, out there stories, and it's great fun with friends if you can get everything set up to allow them to play, being a local co-op game rather than an online one.  All in all, if you want to pick up a game, blast through some levels and beat scores or take on some harsh challenges, give this game a try!

Jamestown strictly speaking is a 'Bullet Hell' game - but calling it that really doesn't do it justice. It has style - awesome music, awesome graphics, awesome gameplay, awesome boss battles! There's really cool ships with different weapons and playstyles, different modes and difficulties, challenges and bonus maps. It's sucked me in for hours and hours, even though technically the 5 levels in the game are beatable in about 5-10 mins each.  I find some bullet hell games are frustratingly hard, but Jamestown remains fun even on the highest difficulties. Every map has unique enemies and a unique boss, and every difficulty adds more bullets to the fray. It's fun replaying maps with different ships, both to challenge myself and to see how differently each one fares.  It's well coded - it has never crashed on me, and works perfectly with screen recording like FRAPS. Unlike flash based games, there are no odd collision or input issues. Altogether the game feels like a masterpiece.

Get some quarters, grab your giant headphones and get down to the mall arcade. It’s time to play a game full of bullets and explosions, where only your reflexes will decide if you win or lose in Jamestown.  The year is 1619. England and Spain are at war, and the conflict has spilled over into the New World. Only we’re not in America. We’re on Mars! Join the colonists of Jamestown as they fight back against the Spanish Conquistadors, search for the lost colony of Roanoke, and more. This top-down bullet hell arcade shooter is everything awesome about video games.  Play through the storyline with four different ships, each with their own playstyle. There is four player splitscreen co-op. The action is tight, fast-paced, frantic, but fair. At times the screen will be positively filled with bullets, and your only hope will be to deploy the Vaunt, a temporary shield that makes you invulnerable and gives you a damage and points boost. Knowing when to deploy it, and when to gamble if you can make it through an attack is a huge factor in your success. Because you only get 2 credits before the level is over. Then its back to square one.  The graphics are charming, full of beautiful depth and vibrant color. Enemies are unique and interesting, backgrounds are lovingly detailed. The art in Jamestown is among the best I’ve seen in an arcade style video game. The music and sound effects are equally top notch. Especially the final level and boss fight, which get my blood pumping and adrenaline racing.  Final Form Games really set the bar high with this game. There’s very little I could nitpick that is wrong with it. I would love to see this in a real arcade machine, with an actual joystick and buttons. This game is screaming to eat people’s quarters. It excels at letting you think you’re just one run away from beating the level, every time you fail. Just one more try…  The story of the early American English colonies is a fascinating tale of survival and hardiness. Throw in Martians, steampunk flying machines and beautiful pixel graphics, and you have a winner of a shooting game. If you call yourself a gamer, get this and play it. It is excellent.

Jamestown is one of the strongest 'against-the-flow' feelings i've had against a game; here is this clearly beautifully crafted thing that for some reason i can't enjoy or appreciate. Everyone says it's great, the reviews do too--so why don't i like it?  Jamestown is, in my mind, not a schmup designed to be a schmup. The rudimentary gameplay is not interesting or challenging enough to sustain prolonged interest, the enemy types are forgettable, the stages are bland and mono-paced, and the same song plays for every level, minus the last--an unforgiveable sin, to my mind, in this genre where ZUN and so many others have set such a precedent and high standard of quality for soundtrack composition. Everyone says this soundtrack is great, and i disagree--it is orchestral, emotionaless, unintuitive, and not at all designed around the experience of FLYING A SHIP SHOOTING STUFF. At the end of the day, Jamestown feels like an experience not designed around itself--the fluff is what makes the gameplay, but the fluff is stupid (no, it's /really/ stupid), and i don't like it and you can't make me like it, and therefore the game doesn't hold much weight by itself. The 'Vaunt' system is kind of cool, but ZUN's done better in every Touhou from 8 onward, so that's not much to brag about.  Anyway. If you think there's a chance you'd enjoy a mediocre shooting experience with an impersonal movie soundtrack and terrible writing, buy Jamestown. i feel i was tricked. this review is brutally honest. i apologize for anyone's feelings that it hurts.
